## Q1. a)

#### Initial Equations:

$$
\Large
\begin{aligned}
x + y + z &= 1 \\
x + 2y + 4z &= \eta \\
x + 4y + 10z &= \eta^2
\end{aligned}
$$\

#### Corresponding Coefficient Matrix:

$$
\Large
A = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 1 & 1 \\
1 & 10 & 4 \\
1 & 4 & 10 
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
1  \\
η  \\
η^2  
\end{bmatrix}
$$

#### Calculating the Determinant of A:

To showcase that these equations lack a unique solution for any value of η, I can attempt to find the determinant. To find the determinant ($\text{det}$) of a $3 \times 3$ matrix, I can use the following formula:

$$
\Large
\text{det} \begin{bmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{bmatrix} = a \times \text{det} \begin{bmatrix} e & f \\ h & i \end{bmatrix} - b \times \text{det} \begin{bmatrix} d & f \\ g & i \end{bmatrix} + c \times \text{det} \begin{bmatrix} d & e \\ g & h \end{bmatrix}
$$

Applying this to the $3 \times 3$ matrix:

$$
\Large
A = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 1 & 1 \\
1 & 10 & 4 \\
1 & 4 & 10 
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
a & b & c \\
d & e & f \\
g & h & i 
\end{bmatrix}
$$

Thus,

$$
\Large
det(A) =
1 \times \text{det} \begin{bmatrix} 10 & 4 \\ 4 & 10 \end{bmatrix} - 1 \times \text{det} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 4 \\ 1 & 10 \end{bmatrix} + 1 \times \text{det} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 10 \\ 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix}
$$
To calcualte the determinants of the $2 \times 2$ matricies, I can apply the formula:

$ad - bc$ where $$matrix = \begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix}$$
